title: Pierrette Herzberger-Fofana
text:
Pierrette Gabrielle Herzberger-Fofana (born 20 March 1949 in <a href="Bamako">Bamako</a>) is a German-Malian politician of <a href="Alliance%2090/The%20Greens">Alliance 90/The Greens</a> and member of the <a href="European%20Parliament">European Parliament</a>.
Early life and education.
Herzberger-Fofana grew up in <a href="Senegal">Senegal</a>. She graduated in Paris in German <a href="sociolinguistics">sociolinguistics</a> and obtained a further degree from the <a href="University%20of%20Trier">University of Trier</a>. She earned her doctorate at the <a href="University%20of%20Erlangen-Nuremberg">University of Erlangen-Nuremberg</a> with a dissertation that addressed women's literature in francophone sub-Saharan Africa.
Political career.
In 2005, Herzberger-Fofana was first elected to the city council of <a href="Erlangen">Erlangen</a>. She was one of the fifteen recipients of the 2009 Helene-Weber-Preis, which is awarded to women engaged in municipal politics. She is a board member of DaMigra, the umbrella organization of immigrant organizations.
Herzberger-Fofana moved into the <a href="European%20Parliament">European Parliament</a> on the 21st place in the European list of Alliance 90 / The Greens in the <a href="2019%20European%20Parliament%20election%20in%20Germany">2019 European elections in Germany 2019</a>. She is currently Germany's only <a href="Afro-Germans">black</a> MEP.
Herzberger-Fofana currently serves on the <a href="Committee%20on%20Development">Committee on Development</a>. In addition to her committee assignments, Herzberger-Fofana is part of the Parliament's delegations for relations with the <a href="Pan-African%20Parliament">Pan-African Parliament</a> and to the <a href="CARIFORUM">CARIFORUM</a>-EU Parliamentary Committee. She also co-chairs the European Parliament Anti-Racism and Diversity Intergroup.
Personal life.
She has three children.
Controversy.
On 17 June 2020, MEP Dr Pierrette Herzberger-Fofana claimed to have been harassed by two Belgian police officers. The accusation was made in the chamber of the European parliament. Brussels prosecutors have issued a criminal complaint against her for defamation as well as for “acting rebelliously and insulting police officers”.
